Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with tax laws and regulations.
Situation2: The deadline for the company's quarterly tax filing is next week.
Story: It was 2 a.m. when my phone buzzed, jolting me awake. I saw my friend’s name on the screen, and when I answered, I was met with sobs. She could barely get the words out—her father had just been rushed to the hospital. I sat up, heart pounding, listening as she poured out her fear and confusion. She needed me to be present, to listen, to reassure her that she wasn’t alone. But as I tried to focus on her words, my mind kept drifting to the mountain of tax documents waiting on my desk. The quarterly filing deadline was looming, and I was already behind. If I didn’t get a few more hours of sleep, I’d be useless at work tomorrow, risking mistakes that could cost the company dearly. My friend’s pain tugged at me, but so did the weight of my professional responsibility. I gripped the phone tighter, torn between comforting her and the gnawing anxiety about the work I was neglecting.
